header.relationships: Close family, partners, very close friends
header.topics: Television programmes, knitting & crocheting, family, books versus eBooks, films, books.
header.conv_type: Discussing, explaining, inquiring, complaining, advising, requesting, anecdote telling, making arrangements

body.u: do you watch The Secret Life of Dogs?
I I should be recording or set it to come on but I tend to just sort of catch it part way in
and the first one I saw they were talking about overweight dogs
and they er invited owners into laboratory conditions and said just prepare your dog's food
and this was all dry food and over eighty percent of owners weighed out too much or or they served up too much food
only about two out of twenty used a a w er a scale or
or a receptacle that w to to measure it out it's like when we feed I've got an old Tupperware bowl and I know that about that far down from the top
but over eighty percent overfed and some of them you could see them they would sort of put some in look at it and go
oh put a bit more in
and they what they do is they set up cameras in people's homes erm or or the environment the dog is in and sometimes it's about behaviours this time it was just about obese dogs
as I said and er there was this little I think it was a King Charles spaniel or something quite little and he was a barrel
and she said they are very careful they weigh his food out and he'll walk away from it in the evenings very often but what they didn't what the lady didn't realise her elderly mother lives with them
and she would sit in the living room with a tray
and the family would sit in the in the kitchen or on the dining room so the dog would go into the living room and just sit like that so mum old dear would every single time would feed the dog
and er they they run a pub

so in the evenings the dog would be down in the pub as well and they put cameras up there and the bar staff erm were lovely to this to the d little dog and all the customers were but they were sort of using the dog as entertainment
and they were sliding them along the floor and the dog was hurtling along so it's er
they said it's actually getting some exercise
so it's better than just feeding it so it's getting some exercise
but it would go through two packets of pork scratchings a night
and then eventually cos it kept looking at it's dinner going mm that's not pork scratchings
but eventually it would come back to it and it would eat all that on top of everything else
and the poor woman was absolutely horrified
that er everybody else was feeding this dog

will will eat everyth er is it Labradors? or? er are known for doing that

it's like a solid wall of food and then the other half the bowl is full
and she she never eats more and she rarely eats less it's half the bowl you can see she's
measured it out she's gone right that's it and then she'll go back to the rest of it later but later could be four or five hours later even
but there's nobody else in the house that will eat it she knows that
oh yeah so she knows it's safe
but the cat will go and have a little look
but the cat and the dog share the same water bowl

so yeah she's never has never gone hungry she's got no reason to to worry and and just eat it all really quickly

it's got a erm er a washable floor but where the dining room part is it's it's carpet
so she'll she'll her food is on the
on the hard surface so she'll go and get a mouthful carry it over to the carpet put it all down on the carpet and then pick it up off there
and I don't know why I don't know why she does it
there's no rhyme or reason unless she just doesn't like standing on that floor
